physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long, typed on plain paper. The words “Little Review (Margaret)” are written in pencil at the top.

div.p:
I wonder how the editor of the “Review” stands opposition when a poor contributor is liable to letters like the enclosed. Who ever would have supposed that my little paragraph poking fun at that ridiculous reading would have been taken so seriously? I have written to Mr. Munro telling him that if you were agreeable I should like to write a serious article on the Poetry Book Shop, its aims and accomplishments. I am greatly in sympathy with the undertaking which is a magnificent one, and I think such an article would be of great interest to your readers and if it appears over my signature it would act as a kind of plaster upon the irritated sensibilities of those people who may have been offended with my sentences. I should not, of course, refer in any way to the sentences in question in the article and I have told Mr. Munro that I think
he is hypersensitive to have taken it as he did.
I have asked him to send me the history of his undertaking and any simple anecdotes that are worth recording, and if you like the idea I will do the article as soon as I hear from him, which would be in time for the January number, I think.
I am seriously thinking of coming on to Chicago either this month or next. I have some things I should like to talk over with you which I think may be to our mutual advantage. I am a good deal amused at Ezra Pound’s advertisement of “The Egoist” on your book page, leaving me out as a contributor when they have published a number of my poems, all owing to a simple difference of opinion which I had with him this summer and which I tried so hard to avoid. Certainly the jealousy of poets is quite equal to the proberbialproverbial one of Opera singers. Yours very sincerely,
